title: Locomotion
text: Crawl your way to physical autonomy.

title: Locomotion
text:
FAQ

What is Locomotion?
Technically, locomotion is the act of moving from one location to another. To me, it is basically crawling like an animal. This practice allows you to reclaim natural movement by developing strength, mobility, and motor control that translate directly into your everyday life.


What is physical autonomy?
Physical autonomy is the ability to do all the things that are important to you. It might be picking something up off the floor without wincing or playing a neighborhood game of soccer and not feeling broken the next day. No matter what your goals are, locomotion can help you progress toward them.


What is motor control?
Motor control is the ability to get your body to do what your brain is telling it to do. It is like being able to pat your head and rub your tummy at the same time. Practicing locomotion develops this skill, increasing the efficiency and ease of all your movements.


How does locomotion do it all?
GMB locomotion uses four basic movements: Bear, Monkey, Frogger, and Crab. There are endless variations of these exercises and ways to link them together. Each movement simultaneously engages the upper body, core, and lower body in unique ways.

title: Locomotion
text:
Locomotion in Small Spaces
You don‚Äôt need much space to move. I love designing locomotion flows for tight spots. Here is one of my original small space routines. Find more of my work on my YouTube channel.

title: Learn to Handstand
text:
Want to learn to stick a free-standing handstand?   Stuck in your solo practice?   Let me help you gain the strength, mobility, and control to nail this cool party trick üéâ

Let‚Äôs Do This

title: Learn to Handstand
text:
FAQ

Why handstands?
They cultivate smiles. They can be done anywhere. Handstand training builds a discipline that can lead to a more fulfilling life.


Can I really learn how to do a handstand?
Of course! Handstands just require a specific mix of strength, mobility, and motor control. I will work with you at your level to develop these fundamental skills.


How often should I practice?
You can see significant progress with just 10 minutes of practice, two to four times a week.


Are there any prerequisites?
There are a few, but not as many as you might think. You just need basic wrist and shoulder mobility along with some upper body strength. Locomotion is a great place to start if you are new to being upside down. If you have concerns about specific limitations, I am happy to discuss them via email.


How will handstands help me grow?
Learning this skill requires consistent, intentional practice. It teaches patience and trust in the process. These intangible results will permeate other areas of your life. I promise.

title: Learn to Handstand
text:
Handstand Tutorial Videos

Essential Concepts
This is a comprehensive tutorial that goes over almost everything you need to get upside down. In our training sessions, expect to practice many of the exercises shown here.



Drills
The two drills that helped me the most were high frogger and the split leg kick-up.



Locomotion For Handstands
Animal locomotion helps you develop the strength, stability, and coordination for handstands.

title: Movement Makes Me Happy
text:
What Is GMB?
GMB is an outstanding organization providing practical tools to help anyone move with ease and gain strength using only bodyweight. They offer a wealth of free educational content and online programs you can do almost anywhere, without special equipment.

title: Movement Makes Me Happy
text:
About Rebecca


I am an engineer and fitness trainer, but most of all, an educator. I am passionate about sharing my knowledge, whether it be about computers or movement. Handstands and locomotion bring me delight, and I find satisfaction in helping others discover this joy for themselves. In addition, I enjoy strength training, rolling around in the grass, and road cycling.
I also really love rabbits üê∞
